Jeff Noh / Mention

Mention

2014 Summer
ios

Mention was an exploratory prototype that gave people a way to send a thought to select friends.

Through an iterative design process, we (Caret Labs) tested our underlying assumptions about text-based communication. Our findings became the underpinnings of an app to follow named Jot.

I designed and built Mention from concept to full prototype in a period of 1 month and continued to iterate on it for 2 months thereafter.

Definitions

I'll use these words throughout this document:

  • Networks: communication services, generally social
  • Messaging: networks deisgned around private 1 to 1
  • Broadcasting: networks for 1 to many or 1 to all
  • Publishing: syn. for broadcasting

Motivations

In 2014, I noticed myself increasingly using messaging apps to send ideas and links to friends instead of posting on broadcasting networks. And it seemed to me that my friends were doing the same.

Why were we doing this?

Context

Massive social networks dominated the landscape. They were arenas full of posts fighting for attention. Friend graphs and follower graphs were bloated. User profiles chronicled a decade worth of posts. Our profiles were our avatars – a collection of posts that painted a picture of our digital selves. And they were being manicured and polished with precision.

Messaging was becoming a dominant behavior. Alternative broadcasting networks were growing. Snapchat. YikYak. Facebook Messenger.

Designing Mention

After many rabbit holes of research, informal surveys, and long internal conversations, it became clear that people had moved and were continuing to move much of their broadcasting behavior from the incumbent networks.

Working Theory

Caret Lab's Theory Publishing on incumbent networks had become burdensome: these networks merged many different contexts of our lives into one; our profiles were permanent histories documenting our lives for anyone to crawl.

Our broadcast networks felt heavy.

Designed for levity

  • Control who receives each message
  • Thoughts live for one day
  • No likes, no follower counts

Outcomes

  • Selective send was not a feature people found useful
  • Conversations that emerged within the thread became the focal point of the app
  • Mention became Jot, an app centered around fast, spontaneous conversations
